title: Relocating to Peoria IL | Discover Area Communities & Culture

widgets.html:
Discover the Greater Peoria Area

True Urban • Boundless Country

In the Greater Peoria Area, building the life you want to live is always within reach. From true urban environs to small-town charm to rural solitude, you’ll find that transitioning from one speed to the next comes as easily as driving over the Murray Baker Bridge. Learn more about what this diverse set of communities can offer you and start building the life you want in the Greater Peoria Area.

Kayla Phillips has always believed a solid sense of community to be the foundation of a good living experience — and that’s exactly what she found in the welcoming, tight-knit community of the Greater Peoria area.

Listen to Kayla’s story.

High Quality Living For Less

When you make your home in the Greater Peoria Area, you’ll find a high quality lifestyle doesn’t come at a premium. Don’t believe us? Check out the cost of living in Peoria and surrounding communities compared with the cost of living in Chicagoland.
Comparative Data Source: Homes.com

Great Outdoors »

Food & Drinks »

Quality Healthcare »

Urban & Rural Lifestyles »

Black-Owned Peoria »

Hispanic-Owned Peoria »

But the quality of life you build here goes far beyond dollars and cents. Pick the lifestyle that moves at your speed, from decades-old farmhouses in wide-open spaces to brand-new studio apartments in the heart of the city. And if you’re looking for things to do, the Greater Peoria Area is never at a shortage, from our breathtaking natural landscapes to our independently owned restaurants and boutiques.

More importantly, you’ll find a welcoming, affirming community with exceptional healthcare and ready accessibility to major markets. Best of all, you’ll spend way less time in your car inching through congested, concrete jungles, meaning more time to enjoy the things you love most.

Education & Training

Ready to start a new career here? The Greater Peoria Area is home to many institutions equipped to prepare you for whichever path you choose.

Bradley University, a top-ranked, private university with more than 185 undergraduate and graduate programs, is located just blocks away from downtown Peoria. With nearly 6,000 students and a celebrated NCAA basketball program, Bradley offers the major university experience in a close-knit setting.

Located about 18 miles east of Peoria, Eureka is home to Eureka College, a private liberal arts college with more than 30 majors and ranked one of the best colleges in the Midwest by U.S. News and World Report. Eureka College alum have been known to go on to incredible things — such as one Ronald Wilson Reagan.

Additionally, Illinois Central College is a public community college with campuses in both Peoria and East Peoria. With more than 170 programs in fields such as nursing, education, engineering, and more, ICC is an ideal choice for attaining your associate degree or setting you up with the knowledge needed for a brand-new career.

Canton, located about 30 miles southwest of Peoria, is home to Spoon River College, a two-year, public community college serving 4,000 credit students per year and offering associate degree classes, career and technical courses, and business and industry training.

The Greater Peoria Area is also a hub for medical education. Aspiring doctors will find a home at the University of Illinois College of Medicine Peoria Campus, a four-year MD program offering clinical experience at nearby UnityPoint Methodist Hospital, OSF Saint Francis Medical Center, Children’s Hospital of Illinois, Proctor Hospital, and UnityPoint Pekin Hospital.

In addition, the Saint Francis Medical Center College of Nursing offers both traditional and online BSN, MSN, and DNP programs with state-of-the-art simulation and skills laboratories located at the adjacent OSF Saint Francis Medical Center.

Finally, Methodist College offers baccalaureate and master's programs for nursing students, as well as health science and social work bachelor’s programs and continued education opportunities for nurses and doctors.

East Peoria is also home to Midwest Technical Institute, a vocational and technical school preparing students for careers in a wide range of fields including mechanical trades, cosmetology, medical and dental assisting, and more.

Of course, the local public and private K-12 schools you’ll find in the Greater Peoria Area will provide your children with the skills they need to succeed in life, no matter which path they choose.
Learn more about the Greater Peoria 2030 campaign.

Questions?

Need more information or advice? We’re here to help.
Fill out the form below and we’ll respond shortly with answers and resources.

title: Hispanic-Owned Businesses in Peoria IL | Shop Local

widgets.html:
Discover Hispanic-Owned Peoria

It is no secret that the Hispanic culture and business community are living and thriving in the Greater Peoria area. Peoria has been welcoming and supportive of new businesses, and Hispanic businesses are participants in the economic growth the city has experienced in recent years. The demand for Hispanic businesses has been growing and shows no signs of slowing down. As the Hispanic community increases, so do the needs they have as consumers throughout the city and, in turn, the sharing of culture through restaurants, retail and the hospitality industry with residents and travelers alike. Discover Peoria is happy to highlight Hispanic-owned businesses that have contributed to the growth of the region and continue to make a positive impact on the lives of not only the people that own them but also the people they serve. 

For more information or to recommend other businesses to include, email info@peoria.org.

City of Chillicothe

Located only fifteen miles north of Peoria is historic Chillicothe, where the rails cross the river. This town grew from its river traffic and ideal location for railroad transportation. The flourishing downtown business district is classic Main Street USA playing home to boutiques, restaurants, barbershops and the Town Theater. 

Chillicothe’s Town Theatre is located in a reclaimed opera house dating back to 1920. After the opera house suffered a catastrophic fire in 1922, the site sat empty until 1926 when it was purchased and reopened as the Sunset Theatre in 1927. After several incarnations and another fire in 1982, the theater is now owned by the Chillicothe Optimist Club. Most notable in this river town is the yearly Summer Camp Music Festival. This multi-day music festival at Three Sisters Park brings more than 30,000 visitors to the town of 6,000 residents every Memorial Day Weekend.

Don't miss Illinois Made maker Triple Dipple's in downtown, where you are encouraged to "eat dessert first!"

City of East Peoria

A quick drive across the Illinois River takes you to East Peoria, where entertainment is never in short supply. Home to the famous Festival of Lights, this marvel of engineering creates giant floats and scenes made entirely of Christmas lights! 

Enjoy live casino action at the Par-A-Dice Hotel Casino and choose from over 900 slot machines, 30 table games and live poker. Par-A-Dice also offers fine dining at Boyd’s Steakhouse or more casual dining at Options Buffet, Nelson’s Deli, and Bourbon’s. Try the all-new Tin Lizard Bar & Grill, the go-to spot for good drinks, great food and the best local and regional bands.

Discover the numerous shopping and dining options in the ever-growing Levee District. Experience any hunter’s paradise at Bass Pro Shops complete with a 26,000-gallon freshwater aquarium and enjoy a game of bowling with dinner at Uncle Buck’s Fishbowl.

Looking for information about this year's Red, White and BOOM? Check out our annual events page for up-to-date information about this year's event.

Located about 18 miles east of Peoria, Eureka is home to Eureka College, a private liberal arts college with more than 30 majors and ranked one of the best colleges in the Midwest by U.S. News and World Report. Eureka College alum have been known to go on to incredible things — such as one Ronald Wilson Reagan.

Additionally, Illinois Central College is a public community college with campuses in both Peoria and East Peoria. With more than 170 programs in fields such as nursing, education, engineering, and more, ICC is an ideal choice for attaining your associate degree or setting you up with the knowledge needed for a brand-new career.

Canton, located about 30 miles southwest of Peoria, is home to Spoon River College, a two-year, public community college serving 4,000 credit students per year and offering associate degree classes, career and technical courses, and business and industry training.

The Greater Peoria Area is also a hub for medical education. Aspiring doctors will find a home at the University of Illinois College of Medicine Peoria Campus, a four-year MD program offering clinical experience at nearby UnityPoint Methodist Hospital, OSF Saint Francis Medical Center, Children’s Hospital of Illinois, Proctor Hospital, and UnityPoint Pekin Hospital.

In addition, the Saint Francis Medical Center College of Nursing offers both traditional and online BSN, MSN, and DNP programs with state-of-the-art simulation and skills laboratories located at the adjacent OSF Saint Francis Medical Center.

Finally, Methodist College offers baccalaureate and master's programs for nursing students, as well as health science and social work bachelor’s programs and continued education opportunities for nurses and doctors.

East Peoria is also home to Midwest Technical Institute, a vocational and technical school preparing students for careers in a wide range of fields including mechanical trades, cosmetology, medical and dental assisting, and more.

Of course, the local public and private K-12 schools you’ll find in the Greater Peoria Area will provide your children with the skills they need to succeed in life, no matter which path they choose.
Learn more about the Greater Peoria 2030 campaign.

City of Peoria

Welcome to Peoria, the largest city on the Illinois River. Formerly the Whiskey Capital of the World, Peoria found its new identity after Prohibition decimated the distilleries. Hometown to Caterpillar Inc., Peoria made a new name for itself in the manufacturing industry. Today, innovators like AutonomouStuff are leading central Illinois into the future of automation.  While the circumstances may change, the fierce spirit of Peoria endures. 

Don’t miss the Peoria Riverfront Museum, the only multidisciplinary museum of its kind in the U.S. This museum offers major exhibitions, a dome planetarium, a giant screen theater and interactive displays for all ages. Or visit the Caterpillar Visitors Center and learn the story of how this manufacturing giant came to be. Take a virtual ride in the bed of a massive two-and-a-half-story Cat 797F Mining Truck. Enjoy interactive exhibits like designing your own Cat machine and see what it’s like to operate heavy machinery as the pros do! Peoria’s strong history in sports is evident with over 10 golf courses to choose from, hockey with the Peoria Rivermen or baseball with the Peoria Chiefs, a Class A St. Louis Cardinals affiliate.  Hungry? The dining options in Peoria are endless. Enjoy delicious pub food and craft beer at Obed & Isaac’s Microbrewery located in a renovated church constructed in 1889. Or try Thyme Kitchen + Craft Beer, a gastropub with unique food options and an extensive drink menu. 

Whiskey. Manufacturing. Sports. Automation. Past, present and future, this is Peoria.

City of Chillicothe

Located only fifteen miles north of Peoria is historic Chillicothe, where the rails cross the river. This town grew from its river traffic and ideal location for railroad transportation. The flourishing downtown business district is classic Main Street USA playing home to boutiques, restaurants, barbershops and the Town Theater. 

Chillicothe’s Town Theatre is located in a reclaimed opera house dating back to 1920. After the opera house suffered a catastrophic fire in 1922, the site sat empty until 1926 when it was purchased and reopened as the Sunset Theatre in 1927. After several incarnations and another fire in 1982, the theater is now owned by the Chillicothe Optimist Club. Most notable in this river town is the yearly Summer Camp Music Festival. This multi-day music festival at Three Sisters Park brings more than 30,000 visitors to the town of 6,000 residents every Memorial Day Weekend.

Don't miss Illinois Made maker Triple Dipple's in downtown, where you are encouraged to "eat dessert first!"

title: Fulton County
subheading: Things to Do in Fulton County

widgets.html:
Fulton County

Surrounded by over 30 miles of Illinois River and 40 miles of the Spoon River, Fulton County offers an escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. The Spoon River Scenic Drive starts at Medina, carving a wide scenic valley through Fulton County as it flows from London Mills to the south and east where it joins the Illinois River near the southeastern corner of the county. 

Since 1968, Fulton County has hosted the Scenic Drive’s Fall Festival on the Spoon River Drive the first two full weekends in October. Are you curious about what life was like on the Illinois River Valley 12,000 years ago? Head over to Dickson Mounds Museum which is a branch of the Illinois State Museum and a National Historic Site. Miles of country trails can be hiked in Lewistown and then topped off with the perfect vintage at Native Trails Winery. Finish your stay in Fulton County at The Canton Harvester Inn which is a four-story luxury boutique hotel.

Fulton County is also home to Big Horse Vineyards in Lewistown. Enjoy a bottle of wine, sit back and relax while taking in the scenic views of the vineyard, farm and the majestic horses. Stop by Emiquon National Wildlife Refuge for more beautiful scenic views, recreational activities and wildlife watching. Also in Lewistown is Orchard Hill Farm, the perfect destination for families to shop for fresh fall items such as apple cider donuts and enjoy activities like the corn maze and barrel train. Orchard Hill Farm also has a series of events throughout the fall season.

Visit Canton lake for an abundance of nature views. Enjoy a day of fishing, boating and hiking or check out their lake view observation deck. Big Creek Park is another popular destination in Canton with a pool, walking trails and many recreational activities. Stop by Elm St Café for a tasty all day breakfast or a casual lunch or dinner.

title: Marshall County
subheading: Things to Do in Marshall County

widgets.html:
Marshall County

Located directly north of Peoria County is a county that is full of rich Illinois history but is quickly evolving to rival the amenities of big cities. In the heart of Marshall County is Lacon, a thriving community with a close tie to President Abraham Lincoln. Lincoln visited the county on at least four occasions and both Lincoln and Douglas visited Lacon in 1854 and were set to both make speeches in front of the courthouse, though neither spoke. 

Located in Lacon is Marshall State Fish and Wildlife Area, the perfect spot for adventuring, picnicking, camping, fishing, hiking and hunting. View wildlife such as waterfowl, great blue herons and bald eagles in their natural habitats. If you're a golf fan, stop by the Timber Ridge Golf Club in Lacon for a 9-hole course.

Located in the center of the town is Marshall County Historical Society, a museum where you and your family can discover the history of Marshall County through intriguing exhibits and hands-on experiences. History is also all around you at The Coffee Hub which is located on the main floor of a building that is 100 years old. Enjoy locally roasted coffee with homemade treats, ice cream from Uncle Bob’s in Eureka and check out the local art that lines the wall. Open seven days a week, there is plenty of time to visit, relax and enjoy a cup of coffee while visiting Marshall County. 

Grab a drink at Zoomiez on the Water. a local favorite riverfront bar located on the Lacon Marina. Don't miss their live music events!

Marshall County’s Old Settlers Festival will be celebrating its 151st year in 2021! This annual county festival is held at the marina in Lacon and features a unique festival theme each year. The festival also features a 5K and 10K, parade, stage entertainment and cruise in.

title: Mason County
subheading: Things to Do in Mason County

widgets.html:
Mason County

Calling all outdoor lovers! Mason County is an outdoor lover’s haven. Chautauqua National Wildlife Refuge in Havana, one of four Wildlife refuges in the state of Illinois, is managed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Services and is also ADA accessible. This refuge is packed with beautiful wetlands, woods and wildlife. 

Discover historic Havana where you can spend the day shopping local boutiques, enjoy a beautiful riverfront park and historic architecture. On the first Friday from May-October, downtown historic Havana comes alive with evening shopping, live music, art shows, demonstrations and much more! The shops and boutiques offer evening shopping, food and drink specials in the local restaurants and free live music. Havana also hosts a Saturday morning Farmers’ Market through the summer and start of fall where you can shop fresh treats and produce. Don't miss Havana's annual Oktoberfest, a festival full of food, music and things to do that the whole family will love.

If you're looking for a good meal, Tall Timbers Marina in Havana is a fun stop for burgers, hot dogs and cold drinks. Visit the marina on foot or by boat, and enjoy you food with the relaxing sights and sounds of the Illinois river. Also in Havana is Rockwell Mound Park, a welcoming landmark of Native American culture. The park consists of a playground as well as traditional Indian burial mounds. 

Mason County is also home to Sand Ridge State Forest, a conservation area filled with native oak-hickory woodland, pine plantations, open fields, grasslands and sand prairies. Enjoy unspoiled nature in a beautiful and unique setting. Sand Ridge State Forest is ideal for a number of recreational activities including archery, camping, hiking, hunting, cross country skiing and geocaching. The forest also has snowmobile, mountain biking and equestrian trails.

title: Stark County
subheading: Things to Do in Stark County

widgets.html: Stark with US!
Stark County Manufacturers

Stark County

On your way out of Peoria County, you’ll run across Tanner’s Orchard, located in Speer on the border of Peoria and Stark Counties. Since 1947, four generations of the Tanner family have welcomed people from all over to an amazing farm experience. This 80-acre farm has become a family destination with a bakery serving noon lunches, a large country farm market with the best apple cider donuts you will ever taste, pick your own apples and pumpkins, a corn maze and the Back 40 Fun Acres with farm animals. 

Stretching through Stark County is Rock Island Trail, a 26-mile long public rail trail filled with prairie grasses, beautiful views and uninterrupted nature. The trail is used for a number of recreational activities including hiking, biking, camping and skiing. Bring your family out for a day on the trail and enjoy the beauty of nature. Just north of Peoria on Rt. 40 also in Stark County, you’ll discover the historic Pony Truss Steel Bridge, a perfect spot to stretch your legs and enjoy the views.

Farther north in Wyoming sits the beautifully restored Paramount Theater. Originally opened in 1934, this theater has closed and reopened multiple times throughout its history. Now, this old school theatre hosts events year-round and is a performance venue bringing culture alive to Stark County. Toulon is where Stark County’s Courthouse and Jail is located, and it is the oldest operating courthouse in the state of Illinois. Built back in 1857, the courthouse has been renovated throughout the years but the original structure remains the same. 

Also in Wyoming is A Few of My Favorite Things Flower & Gift Shop. This specialty store is a fun stop if you're in the area and in the mood for some shopping, and sells beautiful flowers as well as many specialty gift items. 

After a day in Stark County, head out to Catalpa Grove for tasty burgers, steaks, pasta, chicken, wraps, tacos and more. Catalpa Grove is a delicious bar and grill serving up American food that the whole family will enjoy. Their huge menu ensures you’ll find something you love, try out the hamburger horseshoe or the fried calamari and don’t forget to ask for one of their special sauces!

City of Washington

Historic Washington is a wonderful place to slow down and enjoy life. Immerse yourself in the unique and charming shopping opportunities on historic Washington Square. Grab a drink at Faire, a delicious cafe located in a renovated bank from the 1800s.

Visit Five Points Washington, a community center for all ages. In addition to the fitness and aquatic center, Five Points offers banquet and meeting space and theater. The event calendar is always filled with exciting, nationally recognized acts you won’t want to miss.

Washington invites you to come and enjoy the quaint shops, flavorsome dining, and relaxed atmosphere of their historic downtown square. Enjoy ice cream and popcorn from Holland’s Caramel Corn, and buy a unique gift at Sentimental Journey.

Make sure to plan for a wine tasting at Tres Rojas Winery or make a stop at the popular The Blend coffee shop before trying out your favorite new bike at Russell's Cycling and Fitness store.

Washington Good Neighbor Days happens every summer throughout the city, with a variety of festival-related events.

title: Tazewell County
subheading: Things to Do in Tazewell County

widgets.html:
Tazewell County

Located on the East side of the Illinois River lies Tazewell County, one of the Heart of Illinois tri-county counterparts. These communities continue to offer the city amenities known for in Peoria but off stunning countryside views. Fifteen communities call Tazewell County home and we encourage you to discover them all. 

A quick drive across the Illinois River takes you to East Peoria, where entertainment is never in short supply. Home to the famous Festival of Lights, this marvel of engineering creates giant floats and scenes made entirely of Christmas lights! Not only is East Peoria home to the beautiful East Peoria RiverFront and RiverFront Park but there is plenty to discover at East Peoria's most popular destinations including Bass Pro Shops, Par-A-Dice Hotel Casino, ROC Ice Cream & Mini Golf and more!

Founded in 1825, historic Washington is a wonderful place to slow down and enjoy life. Immerse yourself in the unique and charming shopping opportunities on the historic Washington Square and grab a bite to eat at The Blacksmith, a delicious eatery located in a renovated bank from the 1800s. Visit Tres Rojas Winery for some tasty wine, or check out Five Points Washington for events and live music.

The Marigold Capital of the World, Pekin is the largest community in Tazewell County and is filled with unique attractions to explore. Home to the world’s largest sundial, you can spend the day in Mineral Springs Park paddle boating on the lagoon. Enjoy world-class golf courses, Pekin Paintball Park, disc golf, bowling and Dragonland Water Park. Take a stroll downtown on historic Court Street and enjoy an abundance of shopping and delicious dining!

Welcome to the Pumpkin Capital of the World! Morton is home to Nestle USA, maker of the world’s top-selling canned pumpkin, Libby’s Pumpkin. What holiday dinner is complete without a pumpkin pie made from Libby’s? This quaint, peaceful village is rapidly building its image as an up-and-coming foodie destination. Check out Seasons Gastropub for a delicious menu and endless beer or Four30 Scones for mouth-watering baked treats.

title: Fulton County
subheading: Things to Do in Fulton County

widgets.html:
Fulton County

Surrounded by over 30 miles of Illinois River and 40 miles of the Spoon River, Fulton County offers an escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. The Spoon River Scenic Drive starts at Medina, carving a wide scenic valley through Fulton County as it flows from London Mills to the south and east where it joins the Illinois River near the southeastern corner of the county. 

Since 1968, Fulton County has hosted the Scenic Drive’s Fall Festival on the Spoon River Drive the first two full weekends in October. Are you curious about what life was like on the Illinois River Valley 12,000 years ago? Head over to Dickson Mounds Museum which is a branch of the Illinois State Museum and a National Historic Site. Miles of country trails can be hiked in Lewistown and then topped off with the perfect vintage at Native Trails Winery. Finish your stay in Fulton County at The Canton Harvester Inn which is a four-story luxury boutique hotel.

Fulton County is also home to Big Horse Vineyards in Lewistown. Enjoy a bottle of wine, sit back and relax while taking in the scenic views of the vineyard, farm and the majestic horses. Stop by Emiquon National Wildlife Refuge for more beautiful scenic views, recreational activities and wildlife watching. Also in Lewistown is Orchard Hill Farm, the perfect destination for families to shop for fresh fall items such as apple cider donuts and enjoy activities like the corn maze and barrel train. Orchard Hill Farm also has a series of events throughout the fall season.

Visit Canton lake for an abundance of nature views. Enjoy a day of fishing, boating and hiking or check out their lake view observation deck. Big Creek Park is another popular destination in Canton with a pool, walking trails and many recreational activities. Stop by Elm St Café for a tasty all day breakfast or a casual lunch or dinner.

title: Woodford County
subheading: Things to Do in Woodford County

widgets.html:
Woodford County

Woodford County is the largest producer of organic farming in the state of Illinois! While these delicious fruits and veggies are sold throughout the country, you can pick through the freshest batches at our local farmer’s markets. Due to higher elevation and flat plains of farmland, locals claim Woodford county is home to the most beautiful sunsets in the area. 

You can catch one of those sunsets at Metamora Fields Golf Club. Metamora Fields, an exclusively public facility, offers a challenging yet playable experience for golfers of all levels. In the warm seasons, check out Metamora swimming pool, a great destination for kids with water slides. Go on an adventure at Black Partridge Park, which has an extensive mountain bike and trail system filled with fun and thrill. Enjoy the beauty of nature, a kids playground and many pavilions where you can relax and enjoy your surroundings. If you're in need of a coffee break, stop by Eli's coffee shop for tasty coffee flavors and treats. 

In the mood for something sweet after your round of golf? Uncle Bob’s Homemade Ice Cream opened in July 1980 at the Heart of Illinois Fair and now has a permanent location in Eureka. Uncle Bob’s works with local dairies, bakeries and suppliers to ensure their product is fresh and homemade, plus you can even buy quarts of your favorite flavors at local grocery stores! 

Also nestled in Eureka is President Ronald Reagan’s alma mater, Eureka College. This liberal arts and science institution is affiliated with the Christian Church and offers an intimate college experience. Located on campus is The Ronald Reagan Museum and Peace Garden in honor of the United States 40th President. The museum collection houses over 10,000 items from President Reagan’s Eureka College student days, movie and TV career, the governorship of California and his two terms as president. 

Woodford County is also home to Germantown Hills, a blend of small town living with big city convenience. Be sure to check out Buttermilk Café for a delicious breakfast. Kouri's Grill and Bar is another local food favorite. 

Enjoy an escape from reality by visiting Spring Bay, known for its untouched wilderness, serene beaches and peaceful parks. Spring bay is the perfect spot to float along creeks and lakes and for boating on the Illinois River. Treat yourself to a stay at Sankoty Lakes, a world-class wilderness retreat that offers many relaxation and recreation experiences.

title: Marshall County
subheading: Things to Do in Marshall County

widgets.html:
Marshall County

Located directly north of Peoria County is a county that is full of rich Illinois history but is quickly evolving to rival the amenities of big cities. In the heart of Marshall County is Lacon, a thriving community with a close tie to President Abraham Lincoln. Lincoln visited the county on at least four occasions and both Lincoln and Douglas visited Lacon in 1854 and were set to both make speeches in front of the courthouse, though neither spoke. 

Located in Lacon is Marshall State Fish and Wildlife Area, the perfect spot for adventuring, picnicking, camping, fishing, hiking and hunting. View wildlife such as waterfowl, great blue herons and bald eagles in their natural habitats. If you're a golf fan, stop by the Timber Ridge Golf Club in Lacon for a 9-hole course.

Located in the center of the town is Marshall County Historical Society, a museum where you and your family can discover the history of Marshall County through intriguing exhibits and hands-on experiences. History is also all around you at The Coffee Hub which is located on the main floor of a building that is 100 years old. Enjoy locally roasted coffee with homemade treats, ice cream from Uncle Bob’s in Eureka and check out the local art that lines the wall. Open seven days a week, there is plenty of time to visit, relax and enjoy a cup of coffee while visiting Marshall County. 

Grab a drink at Zoomiez on the Water. a local favorite riverfront bar located on the Lacon Marina. Don't miss their live music events!

Marshall County’s Old Settlers Festival will be celebrating its 151st year in 2021! This annual county festival is held at the marina in Lacon and features a unique festival theme each year. The festival also features a 5K and 10K, parade, stage entertainment and cruise in.

title: Mason County
subheading: Things to Do in Mason County

widgets.html:
Mason County

Calling all outdoor lovers! Mason County is an outdoor lover’s haven. Chautauqua National Wildlife Refuge in Havana, one of four Wildlife refuges in the state of Illinois, is managed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Services and is also ADA accessible. This refuge is packed with beautiful wetlands, woods and wildlife. 

Discover historic Havana where you can spend the day shopping local boutiques, enjoy a beautiful riverfront park and historic architecture. On the first Friday from May-October, downtown historic Havana comes alive with evening shopping, live music, art shows, demonstrations and much more! The shops and boutiques offer evening shopping, food and drink specials in the local restaurants and free live music. Havana also hosts a Saturday morning Farmers’ Market through the summer and start of fall where you can shop fresh treats and produce. Don't miss Havana's annual Oktoberfest, a festival full of food, music and things to do that the whole family will love.

If you're looking for a good meal, Tall Timbers Marina in Havana is a fun stop for burgers, hot dogs and cold drinks. Visit the marina on foot or by boat, and enjoy you food with the relaxing sights and sounds of the Illinois river. Also in Havana is Rockwell Mound Park, a welcoming landmark of Native American culture. The park consists of a playground as well as traditional Indian burial mounds. 

Mason County is also home to Sand Ridge State Forest, a conservation area filled with native oak-hickory woodland, pine plantations, open fields, grasslands and sand prairies. Enjoy unspoiled nature in a beautiful and unique setting. Sand Ridge State Forest is ideal for a number of recreational activities including archery, camping, hiking, hunting, cross country skiing and geocaching. The forest also has snowmobile, mountain biking and equestrian trails.

Peoria County

Known as the Heart of Illinois, Peoria County lies on the west side of the Illinois River in halfway between Chicago, IL and St. Louis, MO. Known for having big city amenities in a small-town feel Peoria Country has 15 cities and villages for you to discover. Read on to learn how Peoria County is brimming with possibility- with connections and relationships found around every corner of this tight-knit community.

title: Stark County
subheading: Things to Do in Stark County

widgets.html: Stark with US!
Stark County Manufacturers

Stark County

On your way out of Peoria County, you’ll run across Tanner’s Orchard, located in Speer on the border of Peoria and Stark Counties. Since 1947, four generations of the Tanner family have welcomed people from all over to an amazing farm experience. This 80-acre farm has become a family destination with a bakery serving noon lunches, a large country farm market with the best apple cider donuts you will ever taste, pick your own apples and pumpkins, a corn maze and the Back 40 Fun Acres with farm animals. 

Stretching through Stark County is Rock Island Trail, a 26-mile long public rail trail filled with prairie grasses, beautiful views and uninterrupted nature. The trail is used for a number of recreational activities including hiking, biking, camping and skiing. Bring your family out for a day on the trail and enjoy the beauty of nature. Just north of Peoria on Rt. 40 also in Stark County, you’ll discover the historic Pony Truss Steel Bridge, a perfect spot to stretch your legs and enjoy the views.

Farther north in Wyoming sits the beautifully restored Paramount Theater. Originally opened in 1934, this theater has closed and reopened multiple times throughout its history. Now, this old school theatre hosts events year-round and is a performance venue bringing culture alive to Stark County. Toulon is where Stark County’s Courthouse and Jail is located, and it is the oldest operating courthouse in the state of Illinois. Built back in 1857, the courthouse has been renovated throughout the years but the original structure remains the same. 

Also in Wyoming is A Few of My Favorite Things Flower & Gift Shop. This specialty store is a fun stop if you're in the area and in the mood for some shopping, and sells beautiful flowers as well as many specialty gift items. 

After a day in Stark County, head out to Catalpa Grove for tasty burgers, steaks, pasta, chicken, wraps, tacos and more. Catalpa Grove is a delicious bar and grill serving up American food that the whole family will enjoy. Their huge menu ensures you’ll find something you love, try out the hamburger horseshoe or the fried calamari and don’t forget to ask for one of their special sauces!

title: Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau - Sports Events

widgets.html:
Sports Events

Let's face it: planning a tournament, competition or exhibition shouldn't be a nail biter. So when you're considering options for your next event, talk to the pros at the Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau.

The stats for our area speak for themselves. The Peoria Area boasts a central location, on both a state and nationwide level, and is accessible via major interstates and regional airports. With over 4,500 hotel rooms, your crowds can enjoy comfortable accommodations - many near our outdoor venues for soccer, baseball and softball or the indoor venues for cheerleading, basketball or volleyball tournaments. The cities of Peoria and East Peoria each boast riverside downtowns with dining, shopping, festivals, nightlife and culture – providing plenty of options for fun once the day’s competition is done. These stats, combined with more affordable rates than most major metro markets, make Peoria a winning choice for any group.

The Peoria Area hosts major sporting events in a number of venues year-round. The NJCAA Women’s Basketball Division II National Championship, IHSA Boys State Basketball Tournament and the NSA “B” North World Series are a few of the major events that see success in the Peoria Area, year after year.  So whether it's golf, gymnastics or swimming competitions, your sporting event can truly PLAY in the Peoria Area!

Group Tours

Enjoy the Peoria Area—where a unique menu of experiences awaits you! Whether you are looking for an exceptional motorcoach group tour destination or a hub and spoke location with all the amenities, we invite you to take advantage of everything we have to offer!

Plan your visit today to learn about Peoria’s famed past as one of Illinois’s top distillery towns, the architectural beauty that comprises the picturesque skyline or experience the professional side of Illinois agriculture.

Located halfway between Chicago and St. Louis, nestled along the Illinois River, the Peoria Area gives you big city amenities with small-town hospitality. From our new museum block to musical concerts on the riverfront, there are so many ways to play. Enjoy a minor league baseball game at Dozer Park or a dinner cruise on the Spirit of Peoria, an authentic paddle-wheeler. Peoria has attractions to please your entire group.

So join in the merriment of local festivals, take in a Broadway Musical, indulge yourself at a local winery or simply relax and enjoy all the Peoria Area has to offer. The choices are endless!

title: Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau - Media - About Us - About Our Bureau

widgets.html:
Why Destination Marketing Organizations are Vital

According to industry expert Destinations International, communities like ours compete with every other community for a share of the world’s attention, customers, and investments. To compete effectively, we need to make people aware, create a positive impression, and encourage them to want to visit and experience our community. Attracting visitors is achieved through clearly developing and managing the community’s brand, along with a significant effort to promote, market, sell, and engage potential visitors. And all of this must be reinforced again and again. 

 

Why the PACVB is Vital

Like all Destination Marketing Organizations, the Peoria Area CVB is uniquely positioned to market our communities as desirable destinations. Our support and promotion of Greater Peoria benefits not only prospective visitors, but every resident as well. And not only that, but our expertise in destination marketing supports every organization that is conducting business, providing services, or governing a municipality. No matter the industry, sector, or field, others can benefit from our ability to position Peoria as a formidable competitor among destinations in the Midwest, North America, and the world.

 

About the PACVB

The PACVB works hand in hand with communities in our seven-county service area to create economic growth through sales and marketing of our destination’s facilities, attractions, and hotels. Our efforts attract sporting events, meetings and conventions, and leisure tourists. While these visitors are enjoying our communities, their spending is bolstering our businesses and increasing our tax revenue. In addition, the PACVB partners with the tourism and hospitality sector to ensure our destination offers a wealth of opportunities to visitors, while also improving the quality of life for our residents.

title: Meetings in Peoria, IL | Convention Venues & Facilities

widgets.html:
Meetings and Conventions

If a central location with affordable venues and accommodations sounds appealing for your next meeting or convention, you’ll want to talk with us!

Located in the heart of Illinois and the Midwest, the Peoria Area is just a short drive from Chicago, Indianapolis and St. Louis and is accessible via major interstates.  If you’re traveling from further away, our international airport offers non-stop flights from 11 destinations, along with cabs, car rentals, and shuttle service to your final destination.

The Peoria Area offers great accommodations as well, with over 4,500 hotel rooms to choose from – many of them newly renovated and within walking distance of the largest downstate event facility in Illinois. The cities of Peoria and East Peoria each boast riverside downtowns with dining, shopping, festivals, nightlife and culture – providing plenty of options for fun once the day’s business is done.

Host a convention that gives your attendees the quality experience they are expecting - at a more affordable rate than major metro markets. Bring your next meeting to the Peoria Area!

With over 4,500 hotel rooms, your crowds can enjoy comfortable accommodations - many near our outdoor venues for soccer, baseball and softball or the indoor venues for cheerleading, basketball or volleyball tournaments. The cities of Peoria and East Peoria each boast riverside downtowns with dining, shopping, festivals, nightlife and culture – providing plenty of options for fun once the day’s competition is done. These stats, combined with more affordable rates than most major metro markets, make Peoria a winning choice for any group.

The Peoria Area hosts major sporting events in a number of venues year-round. The NJCAA Women’s Basketball Division II National Championship, IHSA Boys State Basketball Tournament and the NSA “B” North World Series are a few of the major events that see success in the Peoria Area, year after year.  So whether it's golf, gymnastics or swimming competitions, your sporting event can truly PLAY in the Peoria Area!

title: Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau - Planners - Meetings and Conventions - Meeting Venues and Facilities
subheading: Top Places to Meet in Peoria

widgets.html:
Meeting Venues and Facilities

The Peoria Area boasts world-class convention and expo centers, featuring the Peoria Civic Center-located in downtown Peoria and the largest of its kind in downstate Illinois. We are also hosts to numerous convention hotels and 4,000+ guest rooms.

Top Places to Meet in Peoria

Whether you're planning a meeting or a convention for 100 or 10,000 people, consider holding your event in Peoria, Illinois. The centrally located Midwest city, easily accessible via several major interstates, is home to Illinois' largest downstate event facility, Peoria Civic Center. Combined with 4,000 hotel rooms and the helpful staff at The Peoria Area CVB, see why Peoria Civic Center is perfectly poised to host your next event.

The Meetings Centerpiece of Peoria

Peoria Civic Center is Central Illinois' premier meeting facility, encompassing an arena, a theater and a convention center. Inside the convention center, find a 27,000-square-foot carpeted ballroom with 25-foot ceilings, an outdoor balcony with panoramic views of downtown Peoria and its own green room. The ballroom can accommodate up to 1,600 guests for a sit-down meal or break into nine individual meeting spaces.

Also available are 16 meeting rooms, which range in size from 500 to 7,300 square feet. With state-of-the-art audiovisual equipment available on-site—as well as a dedicated audiovisual specialist—each room can be set to accommodate your needs, from classroom-style seating to banquet setups.

For exhibits, the Peoria Civic Center has 110,000 square feet of contiguous exhibit space that can be divided into four separate halls, three of which are column free. Thirty-foot ceilings accommodate large equipment.

The beautiful on-site Theater has a capacity of 2,173 and can be used for performances and concerts, as well as lectures and keynote sessions. To kick off your conference on a high note, consider setting up registration in the 7,000-square-foot Theater Lobby, which has beautiful ceiling artwork, a glass elevator and a spiral staircase, as well as built-in coat check and a bar.

Often used to host concerts like Eric Church and REO Speedwagon, the 12,000-seat arena at the civic center does double duty as a trade show space. It can easily accommodate 140 spaces on its 27,400-square-foot floor, as well as 70 additional booths on the outer concourse.

Winters in Illinois can be brutal, but cold-month meetings at Peoria Convention Center are painless, thanks to a climate-controlled skywalk that provides direct access to 400 nearby hotel rooms. Ask about free meeting space and more perks available to groups that meet appropriate qualifications.

Hotel Meeting Spaces

Combining historic elegance with modern conveniences, the AAA Four Diamond, 286-room Peoria Marriott Pere Marquette Hotel is located in downtown Peoria and connected to Peoria Civic Center via skywalk. The hotel encompasses 18,900 square feet square feet of meeting space across multiple rooms, with the largest measuring 7,500 square feet. If you need an additional room block but don't want to split up your group, the attached Courtyard Peoria Downtown is an easy, convenient option. 

In the heart of downtown Peoria, you will also find the newly remodeled 4 Points by Sheraton that boasts 323 guest rooms along with 12 meeting spaces that are perfect for receptions or conferences, and the largest ballroom can easily serve up to 1,800 people.

The Holiday Inn Hotel & Suites Grand Prairie is one of our areas newest hotels. With its convenient accessibility, located just minutes away from the Peoria Civic Center and seconds from the Shoppes at Grand Prairie,its amazing onsite restaurant, Suite Fire Grill, and with a welcoming sales staff and a venue with all the amenities you could ask for, the Holiday Inn Hotel and Suites is a perfect choice for a meeting planner!

Waterfront Off-Site Venues

If your meeting is headquartered at Peoria Civic Center, you may want to consider an off-site event to give attendees a change of scenery. An affordable, convenient and elegant option is The Gateway Building, located along the Peoria Riverfront. Within walking distance of hotels and numerous restaurants, the venue is only a block from Interstate 74. One of Gateway's meeting spaces, Room 201, has 1,350 square feet of social space to accommodate up to 120 people banquet style.

Convention-goers can take in views of the Illinois River at Peoria Riverfront Museum, which includes several flexible meeting spaces. Host a reception in the lobby, plan a lecture in the auditorium that over looks a beautiful sculpture garden, or make presentations in the 200-seat Giant Screen Theater.

For a truly memorable event, gather your convention attendees in the museum's Dome Planetarium, which hosts incredible laser shows, with private shows available for groups.

More Unique Spaces

Located at The MAXAM Building in downtown Peoria, The Waterhouse Banquet & Catering Facility has three options for meetings: The Distillery Room, which has exposed brick walls and hardwood floors; The Ballroom, an elegant space with indoor balconies and beautiful views of the river; and Broadway Lounge, a multilevel entertainment space that also plays home to Dueling Pianos some weekends.

Another popular meetings facility in Peoria, the Caterpillar Visitors Center features a variety of room sizes for half- or full-day rental. The dining room can seat 104 guests; the classroom hosts up to 50; the smaller conference room holds 16 for board meetings; and the 797 Theater holds about 60.

Peoria, Illinois, offers premium meeting and convention venues for every style and size amid a multifaceted, bustling urban core. Download our meeting planner guide to choose the perfect venue for your next professional.

Tourism In The Peoria Area

Tourism Spending in the Peoria Area Topped $656mm

Tourism spending in the Peoria Area topped $656 million in 2018! Spending generated more than $16 million local tax receipts and supported more than 5,000 jobs. 

Enjoy Peoria is so excited to announce that the local tourism industry continues to see year over year growth according to numbers released by the Illinois Office of Tourism (IOT) back in late July! In 2019 the Peoria Area saw strong growth in tourism spending with more than $656 million generated, an increase of 4.4 percent over 2017. 

The strength of the tourism industry in the greater Peoria Area resulted in more than $16 million in local tax receipts, increasing by 2.7 percent over prior years and the tourism industry employment numbers increased by 0.7 percent with more than 5,000 jobs supported. 

"We know how special the Peoria Area is and we love to showcase the great assets the Heart of Illinois has to offer," said our now retired PACVB President/CEO Don Welch. "We are delighted to see the continued growth in tourism spending and its importance it has on our local and regional economy."

The strong numbers in the Peoria market are reflected at the state level as the IOT announced both international and domestic travel expenditures reached $41.7 billion in 2018, marking the 8th consecutive year of tourism growth in the state. 

"Tourism is a critical part of our economy, helping to boost local and state tax revenue and create jobs," said Jan Kmmerling, Acting Director of Illinois Office of Tourism. "From scenic road trips, stuffing state parks, amazing family-friendly attractions and spectacular nightlife, Illinois offers incredible experiences for visitors all year long."

Throughout the past year, we launched several new marketing initiatives to help promote the region, including the "For Everyone" campaign that included the recruitment video series, billboard campaigns in Chicago and St. Louis, and 47 digital and print ad placements to help promote the region to potential visitors. In addition, we secured 62 events for the region in 2018, with another 117 leads generated fro future convention and sports events. 

We know that the state welcomes more than 114 million domestic travelers each year it is our goal to promote the Peoria Area so that our businesses and local economy can benefit from these travelers," said Welch.

title: Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau - Blog - 10 Peoria Activities Before or After a Meeting
subheading: 10 Peoria Activities Before or After a Meeting

widgets.html:
Activity Ideas

10 Peoria Activities Before or After a Meeting

You’ve planned a jam-packed meeting or convention in Peoria, Illinois, because of its terrific central location, the multi-faceted Peoria Civic Center and other meeting facilities. But what entertainment and activities will your attendees find here, before or after a meeting? Check out tasty restaurant fare, local sports events, and arts or historical outposts. Here are 10 great ways for meeting attendees to enjoy their free time in Peoria.

1) Travel the Illinois River

Whether you join a public trip or book The Spirit of Peoria for a private event, an Illinois River cruise will provide a memorable experience for everyone. Ninety-minute public sightseeing trips begin and end at Peoria’s riverfront dock, and themed cruises are also available (check the website for details). Better yet, schedule one of your convention functions on this magnificent old-school paddlewheel boat.

2) Explore the World

Visitors to the nonprofit Peoria Riverfront Museum can see permanent collections, plus rotating exhibitions and programs, that connect art and science with history and human achievement. The magnificent Dome Planetarium provides real-time trips through the Universe, or you can see a movie in the giant screen theater, which has a 52-by-70-foot screen. This year’s rotating exhibits address genomes and ways in which science and physics create light. The museum can also host meetings and conventions and features beautiful riverfront views too.

3) Learn About A Legendary Corporation

At Caterpillar Visitors Center, visitors get a crash course about the machinery and people who have made Caterpillar a worldwide brand since it began in the 1800s. A leading manufacturer of construction and mining equipment, as well as diesel- and natural gas-powered engines, the company is known for its industrial gas turbines and diesel-electric locomotives.

4) Tour Peoria On Two Wheels

World on Wheels Segway Tours provides a fun and unusual way to ride along the Peoria RiverFront while learning about this area’s history and present-day character. Riding a Segway for the first time requires only brief instruction and practice. You’ll be gliding your way through Peoria before you know it while socializing with other riders. Choose from 30-minute, one-hour or two-hour tours.

5) View Beautiful Sculptures

Enjoy the outdoors and creativity of artists during free guided Sculpture Walk tours, held on Saturdays through October, or book a private tour for your group. Beginning at the Peoria Riverfront Museum, each year-long show incorporates massive pieces crafted from wood and various metals by individual sculptors and displayed throughout Peoria’s Warehouse District.

6) Attend a Minor League Ball Game

Looking for some seasonal fun outdoors? Spend a pleasant evening or weekend afternoon watching Minor League Peoria Chiefs Baseball at Dozer Park. This Single-A affiliate of the St. Louis Cardinals plays in a state-of-the-art ball park, located within walking distance of downtown Peoria and minutes from several downtown hotels. You can also schedule a private meeting or event here.

7) See Professional Ice Action

From October through April, Peoria Civic Center is home to fast-paced sports action, thanks to the Peoria Rivermen Hockey Club. The club plays games against teams that come from as close as Evansville, Indiana, and Columbus, Ohio, or as far away as Mississippi and Pensacola, Florida.

8) Eat and Drink Along the RiverFront

Take one converted railroad depot, serve house-smoked barbecue and fresh tacos paired with craft beers and cocktails, and you have Blue Duck Barbecue Tavern. The popular watering hole flanks Peoria’s RiverFront and showcases pours from regional microbreweries, as well as high-quality 

wines and whiskeys. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the restaurant features a 13-foot ceiling and reclaimed barn wood, alongside intriguing artwork and multiple large-screen TVs.

9) Dine Near Peoria Civic Center

Operating since 1960 and located less than five miles from Peoria Civic Center, Jim’s Downtown Steakhouse is part Old English Country Inn, part pub. You’ll experience an old-school ambience and menu, from tangy shrimp dijon and avocado bruschetta appetizers to fork-tender filet mignon and jumbo sea scallops as entrees. A robust wine and cocktail menu complements live piano music, which begins nightly at 8:00 p.m.

Kickback on Fulton is a relaxed neighborhood bar and lounge not far from the Civic Center. Devour pizza and beer while you take in the latest games, broadcast on large TVs. Its expansive patio is a prime spot to perch during warm weather.

A quick walk from Peoria Civic Center is a lovingly restored 1889 stone church now known as Obed and Isaac’s Microbrewery & Eatery. Fill up on reubens, veggie burgers or bacon-wrapped dates, then unwind over a game of bocce ball or bags outside.

10) Savor Peoria’s Warehouse District and Beyond

For a casual lunch, dinner or late-night snack beyond your meeting site, Sugar Wood-Fired Bistro crafts inventive wood-fired pizzas, such as smokey pork chipotle or pesto arugula. If you’re not in the mood for pizza, the menu also includes hefty sandwiches plus meal-sized salads and handcrafted sweet treats too, at this cozy, rustic restaurant.

Warehouse District gastropub Thyme Kitchen + Craft Beer combines an extensive bar menu with shareable appetizers, hefty sandwiches and burgers, plus soup or entrée salads and decadent desserts. For something different, try the deconstructed duck tamales or vegetarian stir fry.

Thirty-thirty Coffee Co. is a locally owned morning favorite whose employees are deeply passionate about java. A farm-to-cup mentality translates into coffee varietals from across the globe, served at small or communal tables. There’s also free Wi-Fi available.

Elsewhere in town, grab a latte at Zion Coffee Bar or a beer at Rhodell Brewery. Combine craft brews with games at 8-Bit Beercade and late-night burgers at Richard’s On Main, too.

When meeting attendees have a free time before or after the event, this city offers plenty of enticing options. Plan your visit at www.peoria.org.

title: Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau - Meetings and Conventions - Meeting Testimonials

widgets.html:
Meeting Testimonials

"The success of our 2019 Collie Club of America National Specialty Dog Show cannot be talked about without mentioning the contributions of our real Hosts; the City of Peoria, the Peoria Civic Center, the Marriott Pere Marquette & the Courtyard by Marriott, and the Peoria Area Convention & Visitors Bureau. They were all an absolute joy to work with! They took our "Collie Invasion" in stride and worked with us every step of the way to accommodate our every need."

Jean Framke
Collie Club of America
Show Co-Chair

 

"Holding the Illinois Music Education Conference in Peoria has worked for ILMEA for over 30 years due, in no small part, to the amazing work of the Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau!  No question or concern has been too great or too small, and the staff is always available to assist us with creative and workable solutions.  ILMEA could not produce our event without the Peoria CVB!"

Darcy A. Nendza, CMP
Illinois Music Education Association
Executive Director

 

 

“Our group recently needed the assistance of the PACVB while prepping our bid to host the 2019 Collie Club of America National Specialty Dog Show at the Peoria Civic Center. We were amazed when they outlined all aspects of what they could do for us.

The PACVB provided us with an array of needed information on the Peoria area, proposals from area hotels, airport information, and they worked closely with the PCC to apply for and secure funding for our group. Additionally, as we were short on time at that point, did so in an extremely timely and courteous manner! They then went above and beyond, in our opinion, by compiling all the info into an exceptional “Packet” that they allowed us to customize by including any other documents we desired. The end result of their hard work gave us an outstanding, professional addition to our bid.  They were so easy to work with and BOY! did they make us look good!  We needed to beat out a competing bid by impressing 52 Board members!

I believe part of our amazement at the service we received was due to our strained dealing with another venue in the Chicago/Northern Illinois area and total lack of assistance from their CVB.  WOW what a difference! Laura, Cory & Kim at the PACVB made us feel welcome from the very start!  And when we came down for a visit we were further impressed by their hospitality! We not only toured the PCC and Marriott hotels, but Laura & Kim surprised us and drove us around town too!  We could ask them anything and received friendly, prompt, detailed, if we don’t know – we’ll find out, “we are in this together” responses!  Their seamless relationship with the PCC was also refreshing. We absolutely know they have our backs and with their help we know we can and will make our event ‘One of a Kind’!!”  

Jean Franke and Kelly Montgomery
2019 Host Co-Chairs
Collie Club of America

 

"On behalf of the College of Medicine, we would like to thank you for the gift baskets you guys provided us! We had a successful event with over 50 students and about 30 doctors, including a large group who took a bus from Rockford! The prizes were a great added touch that I think shows Peoria rolls out the red carpet to welcome our guests as well as to those students we hope to keep here as they train and eventually practice medicine. Again, thank you for your contributions!"

Dave Haney
Director of Strategic Communications
University of Illinois College of Medicine at Peoria

 

"Thank you Peoria Civic Center, Savor & PACVB! 

I appreciate your time and willingness to work to improve and address the few issues we discussed yesterday.

I have worked with only a few cities in my 20 years of Association event planning and want you all to know that you are serious when it comes to client service, event detailing, focus on success and making us look good to our members.  You all have a high score in my mind and I greatly value your individual roles with the IAFPD Conference!

Kudos to each one of you!"

Cheri Breneman
Illinois Association of Fire Protection Districts
Association Administrator

 

"Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau, Thank you for hosting such a wonderful and successful international conference. The quality and diversity of speakers was excellent, the lunches and social events provided outstanding food and atmosphere for conference members to interact and network. It was a pleasure attending a conference in community that cares about the Illinois River and its resources."

Matt O'Hara
IDNR-Fisheries
Aquatic Nuisance Species and Aquaculture Program
Natural Resources Advanced Specialist
Asian Carp Project Leader

 

"By all accounts and feedbacks, the Midwest Pediatric Cardiology Society and Midwest Sonographer Conferences were overwhelmingly successful.   Many have said this is the best Midwest conference in over 10 years!   When projects like these go well, it is always a TEAM effort.  I want to thank all of you for the hard work and the extra hours to make these events memorable for all who attended. I personally am so very grateful.  I feel truly honored to be associated with all of you."

David Chan, M.D.
Division Head
OSF Saint Francis Pediatric Cardiology

 

“I would like to thank you and your staff – Joni Staley, Cory Hatfield and Kim McKune, for their outstanding attention provided to the Illinois Association of Public Procurement Officials and the 2016 Spring Training and Suppliers Expo. Our group will be booking the same venue for the 2017 Spring Training! Thank you again.”

Jim Smith
IAPPO President

title: Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau - Privacy Policy

widgets.html:
Privacy Policy

Information gathered will be used by the Peoria Area Convention and Visitors Bureau (PACVB) and may be shared with our Members. The PACVB recognizes the importance of protecting the privacy of all information provided by users of peoria.org. We created the following policy guidelines with a fundamental respect for our users' right to privacy to guide our relationships with our users.

Information Collected by the PACVB
The PACVB collects information about users during their registration, their inquiries, their participation in certain activities on our web site, including contests and polls; and through the use of cookies. When users request pages from our server, our web server automatically collects some information about the users, including their IP addresses. These addresses are used by computers on the network to send the requested pages to users.

Information will not be sold or distributed to outside third parties. The PACVB will not reveal any personal information that users provide to us to any third party without their permission, the PACVB utilizes users' IP addresses to help diagnose problems with our server and to administer our web site. We also use it to gather broad demographic information about our users in general. This information does not contain anything that can identify users personally.

Using e-mail addresses provided at registration or otherwise, the PACVB periodically sends out promotional e-mails to our users about services offered by the PACVB. Users can indicate that they do not wish to receive e-mail information from the Peoria Area CVB. Third parties will not contact our users through the use of our e-mail lists.

Our site uses cookies to deliver content specific to users' interests and to honor their preferences. This information is used to assist us in creating a site that will serve the needs of our users.

Upon request, the PACVB will remove users (and their information) from our database or permit them to "opt-out" of any further e-mail or contact.

General
The PACVB is not responsible for the content or the privacy polices of web sites to which it may provide links or the web sites of its advertisers or Members.

The PACVB uses reasonable precautions to keep the personal information disclosed to us secure and to disclose such information only to responsible third parties after permission from the user.

If you have any questions about this privacy statement, the practices of this site or your dealings with the PACVB, please feel free to contact us.
